page.lettertext:
fol.122r
Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L: I was certified from yo
u
the
24 of February, w
ch
was yo
r
L. laste that is come to my
hand
, that her
Ma
ty
liked of my motion for the surplus
of the forces that are in these countreys, when theyr garrisons
are assured to be sent into
France.
If her Hig
nes
bee
resolved to have it put in execution, it wilbee nededfull to
commence to sollicit out of hand. W
th
all as I have written
in my laste to yo
r
L. yt will availe very much, that
M
r
Buzenval
be required to bend his best cogitations to
suade
th
e
heere unto yt. For though I take no delighte to advertise
or censure the actions of others, yet urged therunto for her
Ma
t
bett
r
s
vice I cannot chuse but signify that I
looke for litel help by meanes of his endevours. He
was forward at first to furder the motion, but after a
while I found him fainte, & now of late I have learned
that hee opposeth very hard & practiseth against yt, For
wheras both of us agreed, to feele a far of the affections
of some
sons, by waie of discours, & not as of a thing
that we meant to put in sute, hee hath secretly acquainted
Co. Maurice
& others, that I have bin
e mover of this
matter to her Ma
ty
: wheruppon I am enformed that
e
Count ys somwhat troubled, not knowing how in reason to
gainsay the demand, & yet unwilling altogeth
r
to have
e
Country yeeld unto yt. Whether yt come of some spetiall
designe, or onely of desire to gratefy
e Count, that he
forgat himself so much I cannot signify directly, but I
see
t
his dealing hath bin full of cullusion, & w
th
all
I am afraid, that to smoothe
e humo
r
of Co. Maurice he
hath used some p
r
vention in
suading of
e
Kinge
to refrain
from
t
request for offending this people, w
ch
I also
think
e rather, for
t
w
th
in these 3 daies he hath delt
und
r
hand w
t
S
r
Francis Vere
, not onely not to second mee
but to induce mee to surcease fr
o
parsuing
e matt
r
furder.
Al his reasons are so weake, as I am not to trouble yo
u
w
th
rehersall of any, that wheruppon he insisteth moste
ys a feare that he conceaveth, if the Kinge be thus
releeved w
th
e ayde of this Country, then her Ma
ty
wilbee
slacke in
e sending of
e succour, w
ch
otherwise,
fol.122v
he think
, she would willingly affoorde, But I have
told
him very plainely, that his feare in that behalf, ha
ving
nothing but conjecture, should not move him so much,
as
the greatnes of
e benefit, w
ch
was assured to
e
King
by
e use of those forces, And if her Hig
nes
purse
were
spared for 5 or 6 moneths, it could not any waie
redound
to
e damage of
e King, but rath
r
yt were a meanes
to
drawe her treasure more at length for
e serving of
his
turne, wheras oth
r
wise he might think, that in time
it
would be wasted, w
th
e excessive sommes of mony
that
are daily consumed in
e warres of these countrys, in
her
services by sea, in
e charg
of those 2 regiment
that
are in
Normandy
&
Brittain,
& in other great disbours
ements
for support of
e King
estate. I have also made
him
privy what I heare heere in conference w
th
ma
ny persons
of quality, that setting a
te all private respect
w
ch
may happely move some
ticul
r
province or s
ome
principall martiall men, to keepe theyr forces heer a
t home
the chiefest
te of
e people will finde yt beste,
for
them selves aswell as for the Kinge, to follow
e ex
ample
of
e
Pope,
&
e Spaniard & those of
e ligue, to a
ssault
the enemy joyntly, & to convert all theyr power to
wage
an offensive warre in France, so as nothing is requi
red
for effecting of
e matter, but to use some dexterity
of
remonstrance & entreaty to purchase theyr good liking
whose
backwardnes wee doubt. I have also set him
down
a very plaine demonstration how
e King may
be
strengthend w
th
6000 men fr
o
hence, accounting th
ose in
nomber that were lately sent thether, & that w
th
out
any
prejudice to
e saffety of any province, & that of
nine hundred thousand
Florins, w
ch
is thought wilbe gathered of theyr
public
contribution, for
e
s
vice of this sommer, they ma
y spare
if they list a very round summe of mony for
e
entertainment
of his ruiters, this I thought to be suffic
ient to
make him earnest in a matt
r
tayning to his duty
and to
the
s
vice of his majesty, but in truthe he hath
followed
a very strange course, wherof I could not but
give notice
though I can be well content yf yo
r
L.
be so pleased
fol.123r
not to have yt made knowen, that I have written
this unto yo
u
: upon advertisement heer that
e
Spaniard
in Brittain encrease in nomb
r
& in strength
there hath bin a meeting of
e g
na
l states, to consult
about some meanes w
th
e help of her Ma
ty
that
the course of theyr traffique be not hindred by yt,
but they cannot yet determin what meanes they should
devise, they made theyr answere this day, & gave
it in writing to
e
Empe
rs
Ambassado
r
, w
ch
contayned
litel other, then
e substance of
t
letter, w
ch
I
projected long agoe, w
th
intention to send yt, if her
Ma
ty
had assented to
e Ambassad
rs
at
Bruxeles
I think they of th
e
selves will certify her Ma
ty
what answere they have given, & send a transcript
of
e same, I will oth
r
wise procure it & send
it w
th
e first.
And so I take &c. Hage
1 April 1592.
